utterances: I mean, potentially, the main ways in which this sort of move forward to the winter holiday break really makes an impact on the primaries.
It has more to do with kind of bodies and hands that have done the work of mobilizing.
It has much left to do with the vote.
Really, for a decade now, at every single election, the big story is - it's going to be the youth vote and the reality is, it's never the youth vote.
I mean, the one thing that Obama's campaign can sort of rest easy about is that, really, it's never the youth vote that turns the tide.
It is appropriate for him to continue to try to sort of mobilize his group especially towards thinking towards the generals.
But young people, as enthusiastic as they appear, tend to not make the difference in primary campaigns.
Robert, what about that whole door-to-door, no leagues of young, sweet-footed people going out and, you know, buttering folks up, is that going to make a difference?
Yes and no. I agree with Melissa that, at the end of the day, the youth vote does not turn the tide.
However - in terms of actual votes, but the youth vote does provide a lot of free labor.
They're very energetic, they're very idealistic, and they're extremely enthusiastic about whomever their candidate may be, and this incidence, it, perhaps, could be Barack Obama.

So, what Senator Obama is looking for is actual foot soldiers, people that are going to knock on doors, that are going to drive people to the polls, that - actually, he's basically looking for foot soldiers that are going to bring people to the polls that, ordinarily, may not come out or that may be running the fence; that's what may get Senator Obama to the finish line.

There's folks out there that are undecided, that are saying, you know what, I'm not sure, but you know what, if you pick me up, if you give me a cup of coffee, if you give me a free ride, I might vote for your candidate.
Now, Robert, let's talk a little bit about Mitt Romney - different demographic - talking about the Christian vote here.
He is going to give a talk tomorrow about his Mormon faith.
Will this be an outreach to evangelical Christians or a defense of his Mormon values?
You know, it's interesting.
I talked to the Romney campaign early this morning about this, and they are very adamant that this is not going to be a quote, ""the speech,"" if you will, which is very similar to what John F.
Kennedy did in 1960 when he talked about how the Vatican was not - if elected, the Vatican was not going to control his ideological beliefs.

The Romney campaign is telling me is that this is going to be about religion in general and about religion in the public square, and about how their needs to be religious tolerance or more religious tolerance in this country as it relates to different people's beliefs.
The - I'm told he's going to make a subtle jab, if you will, at folks out there that may say Mormonism is all about polygamy or whatever the case may be.

He's also going to talk mainly about how we are founded on a country where religious beliefs and religious tolerance is the element of who we are as a people, and then he's going to move to the future.

So, this is going to be very interesting to see if, in fact, how that resonates with the American people, particularly with those voters out there in Iowa, in New Hampshire, in South Carolina where, frankly, they may not know a lot about Mormonism.
Once you build this hard infrastructure, there has to be a commitment - and hopefully, now, a commitment upfront - of putting dollars aside to maintaining it forever.
Melissa, this is a country that has become increasingly pluralistic.
You've got a lot more Muslims, people of various faiths, and yet, within Christianity, there still are these distinctions which can cause deep divisions.
Do you think that evangelical Christians, by and large, are going to feel mobilized in a field where no one of the leading candidates really fits their demographic?
I mean, this is part of what makes this particular election cycle so fascinating.
You have a white woman and a black man leading with the Democrats, and a Mormon and a bad Catholic leading with the Republicans.
This is, I mean, darn bizarre, but that's also what makes it - it means that everything is kind of up for grabs.
It's not clear exactly how these, or traditional lines of identity are going to fall out when there's no sort of easy place to run.
So, given that you have a Mormon and a Catholic, where will evangelicals fall?

I suspect that if Romney can do the work of suggesting that Mormonism is, in fact, Christianity, which I think is, really, the central anxiety for many evangelicals who see the book of later Revelation the - of the Latter-day Saints - the book of Revelations that is the book of Mormon, related to sort of the North American conduit as they see that as being outside of Christianity, outside of what is generally accepted as the holy books of the Christian tradition.

I think that it cannot just be about religion tolerance; Romney is going to have to make a very clear and strong statement that Mormonism is Christianity and that, in fact, the kind of world views and morals and ethics of Mormons are closer to that of evangelicals than the behavior of Rudy Giuliani.
Robert, very briefly, Americans seem to want someone who is a - is religious, but some polls say it doesn't really matter what religion they are.
Have we reached that point in American society?
Well, I think most Americans want a president of faith.
They want someone that believes in God, that honors and respects God, and, obviously, that feels very comfortable in the church.
With - what most Americans do not want is someone that's going to, quote, unquote, ""preach to them,"" or that it's going tell them that their religion is better than the others.

And we've done a very good job in this country of making sure that our presidents are, quote, unquote, ""in check."" In other words, that they're faithful, they go to church services, whatever denomination that they may be, but so long as they don't preach to me, and so long that they try to live the best that they possibly can live, most Americans are very acceptable to that.
Well, Robert, Melissa, great to have you on.
Thank you.
Thanks for having us.
Robert Traynham is the D.C.
bureau chief for the Comcast cable network CN8.
He spoke with us from NPR headquarters in Washington, D.C.
And Melissa Harris-Lacewell is a professor of politics and African-American studies at Princeton University.
Good morning.
I'm Rachel Martin, here to tell you that you only have a few more weeks to eat in a posh, Parisian restaurant while in the nude.
O'Naturel opened in Paris about a year ago.
Diners take their clothes off in a dressing room and lock away their phones for privacy reasons, then they take a seat in the dining room for a fabulous meal in the buff.
The owners reassure patrons that not everyone is looking at them.
But easy for them to say - the wait staff is all clothed.
O'Naturel closes February 16.
From NPR News, it's DAY TO DAY.
It his news conference today President Bush threatened to veto a bill that would offer incentives for renewable energy.
The House passed that $17 billion measure yesterday.
It would extend existing tax breaks for solar and wind and renewable energy projects.
And it would pay for that by ending subsidies for oil and natural gas.
MARKETPLACE's Sam Eaton joins us.
Sam, the president is opposed to this bill on the basis of what exactly?
Well, he's not opposed to the bill as much as he's opposed to the way it's being funded, Alex.
Tax credits for expanding renewable energy, everything from solar and wind to energy efficiency are set to expire at the end of the year.
The House bill would merely extend those credits for another three years.
But money is hard to come by these days in Washington, so to pay for it Democrats have proposed cutting $18 billion in tax breaks for oil and gas producers.
Now, that's where President Bush put his foot down.
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: This generally is a tax increase.
And it doesn't make any sense to do it right now.
We need to be exploring for more oil and gas.
And taking money out of the coffers of the oil companies will make it harder for them to reinvest.
Now, Bush also says the bill would raise the price of gasoline, hurting consumers.
So what happens if the tax credits for renewable energy are not extended past this year?
Well, the fear, Alex, is that the U.S.
would not only see less renewable energy built here but it would also fold its cards in the race to become the world leader in renewable energy technology.
Now, that would be a big loss.
Last year investors poured nearly $150 billion into clean energy worldwide, and that's a 60 percent increase over the previous year.
Some renewable energy advocates say the U.S.
is already way behind and they say it's because the tax breaks that we're talking about here only run in three year cycles.
That's basically way too unpredictable for most businesses, which need longer term outlooks in order to attract investors.
So we may be installing lots of wind turbines and solar panels.
But most of them, unfortunately for the U.S.
economy, are manufactured elsewhere, where incentives are more guaranteed.
So if the government took a longer term view, perhaps, longer cycles of funding these things, the thought is this could maybe speed the transition to more renewable energy.
Well, it would help, but it's not necessarily the silver bullet, especially for wind energy.
I spoke to Dan Kammen, an energy policy expert at UC Berkeley, and he says the U.S.
faces a unique set of challenges simply because it's so big.
Many of our best resources, notably wind, are in wide open areas; the prairies; west Texas has been a huge leader; the Dakotas are an absolutely phenomenal resource.
These are places that have low populations and are underserved by big transmission lines.
Well, for those who would like to see the ordination of women as priests, Francis didn't offer much encouragement today.
His response was that that issue, his phrase was the door is closed.
He said that Pope John Paul II had made that definitive.
However, he went on to say that he also wants women to play much more important roles in the church in ways that don't require ordination to the priesthood.
Again, I think this is the signature element of the Francis style.
He delivers a breathtaking new tone, but that tone is placed on top of teachings of the Catholic Church as they've always been articulated.
Well, John Allen, good to talk to you again.
Thanks so much.
Always a pleasure, Melissa.
John Allen, the senior correspondent with the National Catholic Reporter.
We were talking about Pope Francis's 81-minute news conference with reporters on his flight back from Brazil.
Eleanor Beardsley reports.

Every two years, the once humble air field where Charles Lindbergh touched down after his first transatlantic flight is transformed into a massive showcase for the world's most advanced flying technology.
(SOUNDBITE OF SPEAKER IN FRENCH)
For the first time, a Chinese passenger plane manufacturer has set up a booth.
Beijing clearly hopes to establish a beachhead in a market long dominated by European and North American companies.
But some things at the air show never change, like the duel between the titans of commercial aviation - Airbus and Boeing.
This year, after years of delays, Boeing has brought its 787 Dreamliner to wow the crowds.
And Airbus is hoping to score big with its upgraded, more fuel efficient, version of the A320, says Robert Wall, international editor at Aviation Week.
They call it the NEO, the New Engine Option.
And a clear focus for Airbus has been to make a huge splash with the NEO in terms of booking orders.
For NPR News, I'm Eleanor Beardsley in Paris.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Audie Cornish.
And I'm Robert Siegel.
A massive new immigration bill was the subject of a daylong hearing today by the Senate Judiciary Committee.
More than 20 witnesses testified before the panel, either to applaud the bipartisan legislation or to question it.
But overshadowing the event was the bombing of Boston's marathon one week ago, with two suspects who immigrated to the U.S.
as refugees a decade ago.
Joining me from the Capitol to talk about today's hearing is NPR congressional correspondent David Welna.
David, this was the second day of hearings on the immigration bill that the Gang of Eight, as it's called, rolled out last week.
On Friday and today, the Boston bombings, very much on the minds of everyone, including the senators holding the hearings.
How did that play out today?

Well, Robert, this is something that's been building up ever since Friday's hearing when Chuck Grassley, who's the top Republican on the Judiciary panel - and something of a skeptic about this immigration bill - first raised questions about how the case of these two brothers might shed light on weaknesses in the immigration system.
Democrats reacted to that over the weekend, saying opponents of the bill were trying to torpedo it by using the outrage over the Boston bombings.

And today, these rising tensions sort of exploded between Grassley and New York Democrat Charles Schumer, after Schumer stated at the hearing that the American people overwhelmingly favor immigration reform and that they won't be satisfied with calls to for delays and impediments to the bill.
I say that particularly to those who are pointing to what happened, the terrible tragedy in Boston, as a - I would say excuse for not doing a bill or delaying it many months or years.
I never said that.
